ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Global Companies - Dallas Terminal, owned by Global Partners LP (Global), is a refined petroleum products storage and distribution facility. The Terminal stores and handles various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, butane, ethanol, and petroleum based additives. This document pertains to the Butane Blending Process operated at this facility, which has been identified as a Program Level 3 process.

The Dallas Terminal in Dallas, TX is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Global believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding EHS performance is of paramount importance.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Global has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The RMP regulated substance handled at this facility is butane, a flammable gas handled as a liquid under pressure (LPG). By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Global is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive trai

ning is provided to employees and contractors/visitors which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Dallas Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports), stored in one (1) pressurized storage vessel, and blended into gasoline. The process is designed to minimally meet the stipulations identified in National Fire Protetion Association code No. 58 (NFPA 58) and includes the applicable engineered and operational safety features specified.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

Global's accidental release prevention programs along with emergency planning and response programs allow affective management of the hazards posed by Butane to our employees, the public, and the environment. The covered process is regulated by the EPA RMP regulation 40 CFR Part 68, as well as the OSHA Process Safety Management standard 29 CFR 1910.119. The following accident prevention program elements are in place at the Dallas Terminal:

01) Employee Participation
02) Process Safety Information
03) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) with Risk Assessments
04) Standard Operating Procedures
05) EHS and Operator Training
06) Contractors
07) Pre-startup Safety Review
08) Mechanical Integrity with Preventive Maintenance
09) Work Permits
10) Management of Change
11) EHS Accident or Potential/Actual Catastrophic Event Investigation
12) Emergency Response
13) Compliance Audits
14) Trade Secrets

These fourteen (14) individual elements of the Global Companies - Dallas Terminal prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Global and its employees are committed to the standards required by these management programs. In addition to the above elements, Global also employs specific prevention measures that are incorporated into the process operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and

reduce the consequences of a release. These are briefly summarized as follows:

General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures include:

-Process is engineered and constructed (as a minimum) in accordance with recognized industry and company standards.
-Equipment is properly designed and includes protection from overpressure (pressure safety/relief valves).
-Technical drawings including Piping & Instrument Diagrams and Process Flow Diagrams, are available and maintained.
-Operating systems are monitored and controlled by trained Operators.
-Computerized monitoring and control of process operation is in place.
-Redundant control systems are provided.
-Automatic and manual shutdown devices are installed for critical systems.
-Instruments, analyzers, and safety devices are maintained in accordance with industry standards.
-Facility access is controlled.
-Regular safety meetings are held and safety awareness programs in place.
-Routinely scheduled safety inspections and audits are performed.
-The process area is surveilled by operators.

General Release Mitigation includes:

-Automatic (ESD and thermal actuated) and remotely operated emergency shutoff valves are installed to limit release quantity.
-Valves to isolate leaks are installed strategically throughout the process.
-Hydrocarbon detectors are situated at key areas to warn of a chemical release and automatically shut down the process.

General Emergency Response includes:

-An emergency alert system is in place.
-Periodic emergency training is provided for employees.
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies are in place and regularly verified.
-Emergency drills are performed with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Dallas Terminal Butane Process complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA 58 [2014 at time of

construction]) requirements for LP Gas storage. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, if a release does occur, a Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and the Dallas County LEPC.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Global Companies - Dallas Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The terminal keeps records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the chemical release of materials (butane) covered under the EPA RMP regulation.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Response actions are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department. A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

In the event of an emergency involving the Global Companies - Dallas Terminal butane blending process, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire response capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Dallas Fire-Rescue Department and the Dallas County LEPC. The Dallas Fire-Rescue Department regularly participates in training and exercise sessions for this Facility.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Global is continually striving to make the Global Companies - Dallas Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Global looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. The Dallas Fire-Rescue Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, Global wo
rks cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.
